did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: This collection contains a "Shooting Final" screenplay, written by Gerald Drayson Adams in 1953, and related materials. Titled Three Young Texans, the story is set in the 1870s and centered around a train robbery in Texas.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Born in 1900, Gerald Drayson Adams wrote film stories and screenplays from the 1940s to the 1960s. He specialized in western movies and television shows, most of which are lesser known, but ended his career by writing stories for two notable films featuring Elvis Presley: Kissin' Cousins and Harum Scarum. Adams died in 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of one series, Literary Productions, and this series consists of items related to a "Shooting Final" screenplay, dated 1953 July 14, for the film Three Young Texans. Written by Gerald Drayson Adams, the screenplay is 114 pages in length, and contains a series of revisions made by Adams shortly before filming. It also contains a shooting schedule and listings of the film's cast and staff. Two call sheets are also found in the collection. The collection is in good condition.

Three Young Texans, written by Adams for the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, was shot in 1953 and released in 1954. Its plot is centered around an 1870s train robbery in West Texas, near the Rio Grande River. The movie starred Mitzi Gaynor, better remembered for her role in South Pacific (1958), and provided one of Aaron Spelling's first acting roles. Spelling went on to be a successful film and television producer from the 1960s into the early 2000s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to current processing, this collection was housed in a single folder with a basic description. The collection has been re-foldered and now has one series, Literary Productions.
